name: TV's Worst Moments Quiz | TV Mixture | 10 Questions

questions.text: TV Show 1: Generally considered to be the hands-down worst tv show of all time, 'My Mother, The Car' had Ann Sothern (voice only) as a woman who is reincarnated (if that's the right word) as a car. Who was the star of this show?
questions.explanation:
Jerry Van Dyke.

	Ugh! Ugh! Ugh!

questions.text: TV Show 2: Following up on the success of 'Laugh-In', another show tried to duplicate the madcap, rapid-fire format - with disastrous results. The show was dumped - with incredible speed. What was the name of the show?
questions.explanation:
Turn On.

	The others were legitimate shows: 'Checkmate' starred Sebastian Cabot, 'Caribe' was an adventure series, and 'Way Out' was a short-lived sci fi series.

questions.text: News 1: TV newcaster Tex Antoine - best known for doing the weather - all-but-destroyed his career with a tacky comment about what subject?
questions.explanation:
Rape.

	He came on after a news story about rape. His comment (paraphrased) was: 'If rape is unavoidable, relax and enjoy it'. Gives new meaning to the term 'Bad Judgment'.

questions.text: News 2: Chris Chubbock made news during a broadcast from Lubbock, Texas by doing what on the air?
questions.explanation:
Shooting Herself.

	Apparently unhappy about a romantic situation, she shot herself fatally on the air.

questions.text: Sports 1: NBC caught a ton of flack when it broke away from a sporting event so that 'Heidi' could be televised exactly at 7:00 P.M. Sports fans were very unhappy when they missed some significant action at the game they had been watching. What kind of sporting event was being televised?
questions.explanation:
Football.

	A pro football game between the N.Y. Jets and the Oakland Raiders. Two touchdowns were scored after the network broke away from the game. Stupid.

questions.text: Sports 2: NBC again. Earlier, in 1967, the chief NBC sports broadcaster repeatedly promised that the great pennant race in the Ameican League (between the Red Sox and the Tigers) could easily go down to the very last day. It was promised that 'NBC will be there until the matter is resolved. On the last day of the season, with the pennat winner still in doubt, NBC televised the Red Sox game and switched periodically to coverage of the first game of a doubleheader between the Tigers and the Angels. Then, when the Red Sox game was over and the first game of the Tiger doubleheader was over - with the pennant depending entirely on what happened in the second game of that doubleheader - NBC didn't televise the game. Who was the broadcaster who kept saying 'we'll cover the race until it's decided'?
questions.explanation:
Curt Gowdy.

	It was Curt who was the top man at NBC in those days. The cameras were there - what happened? Stupid.

questions.text: Commercials 1: The worst ad of all time (in my opinion) features a woman who becomes emotional and nostalgic as her daughter prepares to get married. What is the product that is being advertised?
questions.explanation:
Baby Powder.

	'I used this on you when you were a baby.' Corny, hokey, transparent. Dreadful.

questions.text: Commercial 2: Someone once told a copywriter that it was a good idea to mention the product's name during an ad. So, a product known as 'dippity doo' (no kidding) was advertised on tv with a jingle that consisted only of saying the product's name over and over again. What kind of product was it?
questions.explanation:
Hair care.

	It really gets annoying after you've heard the product name about ten times in thirty seconds.

questions.text: Entertainment 1: Tiny Tim's wedding on national tv was an event: this 'freak show' had a huge audience. What TV show host televised the wedding?
questions.explanation:
Johnny Carson.

	I wonder if the audience laughed or cried?

questions.text: Entertainment 2: It doesn't belong in this category, but it may be one of the most famous moments in TV: Ed Ames throwing the tomahawk on TV - and showing incredible aim. Ames played an Indian on what tv western?
questions.explanation:
Daniel Boone.

	He played Mingo. Fess Parker starred. What a shot!
